reviewText:
Critical Mass is an action puzzle game where you match colored blocks to remove them.  The more of a color you remove, the bigger the combo. This review is from a disabled gamer (I only play with a mouse).

http://youtu.be/a6Kdsyvsaks

Loading the game, you can easily access options and change the game to Windowed Mode.  Windowed Mode is borderless so you can change windows without exiting the game.  There's multiple resolutions you can set the window too.  It also has Colorblind Mode which adds a symbol in addiction to the blocks color.  Another option I was impressed with was the Mouse Button option that let's you swap each buttons role.  There's also a single option for the mouse but it seemed to be picky on exactly where I cllicked which slowed me down.  I opt'd to keep using  the reversed option.

Actual game modes include Classic, Survival, Meditation and Rush.  While most modes do require you to work within various time tables, Meditation is a completely untimed relaxing strategic gameplay.  To play the game, rotate the mass with your left mouse button and place blocks with your right mouse button. Many games actually didn't require much rotation so I completed many levels using only 1 mouse button.

If you're a mouse user who can left & right click gameplay should be a breeze!  Colorblind gamers should also be fine with colorblind option enabled.  It's actually my favorite way to play.

reviewText: I hate bashing on Ozzie companies. ;p And this isn't an evil, unplayable game. My first impression was good, I played it for a bit, expected to play more, had it installed forever, yet every time I fire it up, I close it after 5 minutes.\n\nIt's a match 3 game with some 3D tetris elements. The concept is good. The graphics are polished. The music isn't bad. The controls feel annoying at first, but they're actually mostly okay. The problem is, the gameplay doesn't feel satisfying. It expects (and rewards, scorewise) big combos and long term strategy. It also expects you to be fast and responsive. This should theoretically work, in that zen-like way games like this work, but it doesn't. The rythym and pacing feels all off, it feels like the speed jumps from 1,2,3,4,5 to 50 to 150. Once you get into the zone and start planning ahead for later big score combos, it feels like you blink and the game jumps speed, asking you to go for quick, just don't make a mistake" placement. That may be totally subjective of course
date: or it could be that the feeling gets exacerbated by the clunky cube placement process. It simply isn't visually always obvious or easy to correctly target the location you want on a constantly rotating cube
recommended: which really hurts the game when it picks up speed. People misplace blocks on tetris too
hoursPlayed: but usually feel it's their fault
voteText: here it feels like the cube jumps place three times before you can be sure it's where it should be. By which time the game has jumped two speed gears and you're basically done with.\n\nAgain
votesHelpful: in theory. I just never feel like playing it long
votesTotal: because it doesn't feel very enjoyable. The thumbs down is just trying to balance a "very positively" reviewed game
votesFunny: with an 80 something metacritic score that few people seem to actually play much (notice the curiously short play times of the majority of the positive reviewers?). So I'd suggest to approach with caution
commentsCount: and at least play the demo first."

reviewText: They weren't kidding when they wrote up the description for this little gem. Brutally simple to learn, simply brutal to master, Critical Mass is the kind of game literally anybody can just pick up and waste hours upon hours of their lives playing, all in a vain attempt to top the charts. And don't think for a second I mean any of that in a bad way. Far from it; Critical Mass possesses a fun, addictive quality rivaled only by the likes of Tetris and similar titles.\n\nIn case you still have doubts, bear in mind that this game only costs a measely two bucks, so it won't be a serious dent in your pocketbook even if you turn out to be one of the four or five people globally who don't enjoy it (you know who you are). With that in mind, what do you have to lose? I pride myself for being more discriminating than most when it comes to choosing which games to buy with a rather limited budget, so believe me when I say Critical Mass is a nearly fool-proof purchase!

reviewText: This game is immediately very fun, that is the first thing to note. From the very first moment you start it, you'll be hooked, and an hour will have passed before you know it. Along with the great core game, the audio and visuals are sublime. After my first session of playing this game, I started looking on Steam for it's soundtrack. The art, as well, is execlent. I haven't spent much time playing it yet, but that's going to change very soon.\n\nMy only issue with this game is that the cubes won't appear if you're using Mac OS and have the in-game overlay turned on. It is, however, a very easy issue to remedy; under your games library, right-click the title, select properties, and disable the in-game overlay. Then, everything will run fine.

reviewText: This is a simple extension into the third dimension of a typical match-x game. You start with a vaguely cube shaped pile of blocks and then fire predetermined color blocks onto the mass attempting to connect at least four of a color, causing them to be removed. In it's base mode each fired block causes the mass to grow while matching blocks causes it to shrink. Take too long or fire too many blocks without clearing any and you'll reach critical mass and lose.\n\nThe interesting thing about this game is that at it's heart it seems to want to be a competitive game. In the base mode there are only 10 levels and they have to be completed in one sitting to get a final score and attempt to get on the leaderboard and this leaderboard seems to be what the developers hoped would keep you coming back. Personally I'm not really a fan of this type puzzle game and the competitive aspects are not a draw to me. If you enjoy doing something multiple times in an attempt to hone your skill then this will be well worth the price of entry. If, like me, you're looking for a more encapsulated experience then its probably best to move on.

reviewText:
A funny little game.

So I have palyed a small amount of this game, andI I can say it feels like Bejewled. Not the way it plays, but more like the fact that it`s a time killer, it`s ment for you to play like 10 minutes, and then come back to it.

The game is about maching colloured blocks, that are stuck in a cluster in the middle. There are some power ups like a time slower and a multiplier, which will come in handy.

Overall the game is really fun, and there are tons of modes to play. Of couse the goal are the same, but it becomes a bit more of a challenge, when the timer you have to work on is halved!

The problem I have with this game, is that I find it boring, much faster than many other time killer games. I don`t really know what it is. Maybe it`s the play still or the presentation, that gets me off

I give this game a thumps up. 4 out of 10

reviewText: Not recommended for a few reasons, mainly - the achievements. This is because I am a big achievement hunter so when games do things like THIS game does, it really annoys me. At least 5 of the achievements (maybe more, I forget) require you to get to Rank 1 on the leaderboards in each game type as well as the Overall leaderboards. This is impossible through legitimate play as the current Rank 1 players are clearly hackers, so there is no way for anyone to claim those achievments legitimately. If they had weekly or daily leaderboards it would make much more sense. That being the main reason, this game also fails at what it claims to be action-puzzle." Sure it can be fast paced but it's almost impossible to do extremely well just because the game lends itself to being a slow paced strategic game. You can't see your next block color
date: it doesn't have any indication how close you are to losing etc. Which are all sort of staples of said action-puzzle games. Don't buy it 1/10"

reviewText:
Critical Mass is a rare specimen. It is the first game I have ever seen that actually looks like it would be easier to play on a tablet. To me that is amazing, I mean... touch screens are usually so finnicky and unreliable, and as a society we have used computers for decades, we've been brought up on them! But Critical Mass is actually hard to play using a mouse... A touch screen would make this game great.

Props to the developer for thinking of a playstyle that would be completely at home on the huge boon of tablet devices out there today.

On steam? Yeah it's alright. Time based, 3D match 4 game. Match 4 blocks, they explode. Clear the board before the mass of blocks goes critical and blows you up (I'm guessing that's what happens). Feels awesome, looks awesome (fantastic UI) and has worldwide leaderboards for each level and game mode. As stated, it's finnicky to play, but rewarding, and I could see some people really getting into it.

reviewText: Critical Mass is a action puzzle-solving 3D game taking place in space, where you use the mouse buttons to rotate and place blocks. You start off with a cluster of cubes and your objective is to connect 4 or more, successfully make your way a little closer to zero.. or not and gradually it will start zooming in towards your inevitable fate.\nSounds familiar? it's basically modern time tetris with a twist to it. My biggest problem with this game is the way the mechanics work, having everything in 3D can be very disorienting at times and given that you have the cursor pointing at an object isn't normally that hard but adding also that you're rotating the object at the same time makes it easy to misplace blocks which can be very annoying where you're playing the more time consuming levels.

reviewText:
Critical Mass is a puzzle game where you clear the field of blocks by matching sets of four same-colored blocks, as fast as possible. In this game, speed is much more important than smart block placement, so the game tends to be hectic and fast-paced (though, I usually prefer games that are the other way around). The game works pretty well, for the most part, and the puzzle action is fun. The graphics are clear and functional, though not terribly pretty, and the sound works, but you don't lose much by muting the sound.

The achievements for this game are unfair. Many require you to reach the top of the leaderboards.

If you're a fan of puzzle games and like challenges that require you to think quickly, or if you enjoy the competition of online leaderboards, then this is the game for you. Other puzzle fans should consider Critical Mass, especially since the price is good.

This game was a lot more fun than i thought, i just bought it for the lolz from the steam winter sale 2013 because it was 0,50€ and i was quite suprised how fun it was. I would defienedly recommend it to anyone who just likes to relax and play easy" puzzles!"
This game is fun to play in short bursts.  You have a cube and other cubes come flying at it, you match the colors to keep it from getting too big and exploding.

Definitely an interesting and visually-attractive take on the standard four-in-a-row colour matching formula, but in practice it's just too fiddly for us to truly recommend. With some more tweaking to the gameplay mechanics and notification area, this game has the potential to be a great-looking, addictive puzzler, but at the moment it's simply too frustrating to play.

A frenetic match 3 puzzler painted with vibrant color and absorbing gameplay.  The object is to simply eliminate the cubes in the playing field before the field reaches Critical Mass.  It's cheap, it's great and it's worthy so why isn't it in your library?

reviewText:
I really want to like this game.  Truly and sincerely, it is almost a good game.  I love what it's trying to go for.  Unfortunately, it is a single-player game with a bizarre and unfathomable reliance on having a constant internet connection, apparently in order to enable the leaderboard.  It is physically difficult to play it offline, and the steam forums for it are full of people with various technical problems -- like having the main game interface not load, or the automatic attempt to log in crashing the game.

It could have used a little more polish.

Unfortunately, the lack of polish extends all the way to the game design, too.  Critical Mass can't decide if it wants to be frantic or strategic, and ends up being neither instead of both.  If you go too long without making a combo, the puzzle swells to take up more and more of the screen, and it gets harder and harder to see what's going on -- which encourages carelessness, which only makes the problem worse.  The timer for how long you can go without making a combo is also significantly too short -- rather than adding intensity to the game, it just stops me from being able to build up any kind of a rhythm.

There are so many tiny details that counter-productively disrupt eachother, rather than produce a coherent experience.

All of that said, it's still a really neat idea, and it works well enough to give you a taste for the game they *tried* to make.  I eagerly await either a slightly better-polished copycat game, or a patch that might make Critical Mass feel a little more finished.  I don't regret buying it a bit, but I also don't see myself playing it more than an hour a year, as I periodically forget and remember its existance.

If there is ever a patch, I will update this review.  Until then, don't pay more than a dollar.

reviewText:
Great idea, hampered by annoying controls and viewpoints - the reasons tetris 3D didn't take off. Firstly viewing in 2D, and secondly controlling using a mouse to point and rotate. All this while the blocks are expanding and approaching a time-limit for self-destruction. It's a game that would work well once you can control and see what you're doing, but ultimately I found the fiddly controls too frustrating.

I do commend the designers though, the presentation of the game is great. It's just a practical issue of selecting in 3D with precision against a timer. It's like playing a 3D game of chess against a timer where you have 10 seconds to make a move each turn. The two aren't compatible unless you're a 4-dimensional being with access to 3D-vision.

I would play this on untimed modes.

reviewText: 3D cube matching game where you must race to match colors before the whole structure gets too big and hits Critical Mass. You basically have two options: rotate or place and the gameplay doesn't get any more complex than that. There's 4 different game modes, but they really don't feel vastly different. The game doesn't even provide basic gameplay elements like a heads up about what the next color is so you can strategize accordingly. It's a different spin on the classic Tetris game, but it was unable to hold my interest for more than a couple hours.

reviewText:
Critical Mass is a match-four puzzler where players place different colored cubes in a three-dimensional space. The player must eliminate all cubes in the game area before reaching critical mass". Scoring combos will reduce the critical mass level and buy the player some time.

This game features several play modes. Classic proceeds through several levels of predefined shapes with randomized arrangements. Rush requires the player to remove all the blocks while the score decreases. Survival requires the player to stave off critical mass for a set period of time. Meditation gives the player a set number of blocks to remove with no time limit or failure conditions.

As far as gameplay goes
date: scoring a combo does have a good feel to it and the game itself is reasonably polished
recommended: however this game fails to get my recommendation. Firstly
hoursPlayed: the since the game involves a three-dimensional shape
voteText: the gameplay often devolves to a guessing game where the player may (or may not) get lucky by placing a cube on a hidden vein of like colored consecutive blocks.  Secondly this game's music is quite literally a 10 second
votesHelpful: clip on loop. Meditation features a different 10 second clip but the rest are the same. Lumines
votesFunny: changes the visual style and music as the player progresses which keeps things fresh and interesting.\n\nTo it's merit the game can be played with just the mouse
commentsCount: so if you're looking for a game that can be played with one hand (maybe with a beer in the other hand). Also the developers were thoughtful enough to include a colorblind mode which adds a symbol to each block.\n\nScore: 5/10"

reviewText: I just can't recommend wasting time or money on this unless you have exhausted all the better puzzle games on Steam. Including the ones that came out after this. In fact, just wait for another one instead of buying/playing this. The modes all seem samey, the scoring seems semi-random, leaderboards and achievements are broken (and this is just what I SPOTTED, god knows what didn't work under the surface) and to top it all off it was never really enthralling like a good Bejeweled or Squarelogic or whatever your puzzle drug of choice is.

reviewText: Meh. 8/8

reviewText: An interesting idea: you have a limited amount of time to remove all the blocks by matching four or more of the same coloured blocks. The three dimensional nature of the game does mean it can be quite frustrating though as there were numerous situations where a block was misplaced and the blocks you're given to place with are random which adds an obnoxious layer of RNG ♥♥♥♥ery. You would probably be better off playing English Country Tune or Puzzle Dimension before even considering Critical Mass.
voteText: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Reaches critically boring mass quickly. I was waiting for the game to add anything interesting, but you soon realize that all you get is what you see in the first minute or two of gameplay. I'm not a fan of Tetris, but Tetris is more interesting than this. If you want a 3D block-vanishing game, Block Out did it better in 1989 for the Amiga.
Overall a game I wouldn't use a PC for anyway. Maybe ok for a mobile time waster game. On PC there are plenty of more interesting games.

reviewText: Critical Mass has a good concept, but the choice of color ruins the experience. It uses red, orange and yellow (and a bunch of other colors). The issue happens when you want to place one of the three colors, because when you're choosing a spot" for your block to land
date: it's done with a transparent representation of that block. That means that red will look orange next to orange
recommended: yellow will look orange next to orange and red
hoursPlayed: and orange will look whatever it damn wants between the two.\n\nIt sounds like a minor nitpick
voteText: but it causes you to make mistakes even if you are not colorblind. It's really inexcusable in a color-based puzzle game."

reviewText:
UPDATED DEC 2015:
Since the developers cared enough to FINALLY fix the game after almost 4 years I think it only fair I change my review to reflect that.

Game seems to have it's online bugs fixed.
Game does what it says on the tin now.
A good match 4" cube game based on speed/timer and reflexes.
There is a "medatation mode" for those of us (me) who hate timers.
Basically it's a match-3 game with cubes. Runs really well. The biggest issue is you can find these games by the thousands online for free. However
recommended: \nso if those are important to you and the price is right

reviewText:
Could only take this for 15 minutes before getting entirely bored of it.
Graphics: Smooth enough, but literally just cubes.
Sound: I hope you like one 20-second loop played endlessly.
Gameplay: Simple, uninteresting. Probably an original spin on this genre but the genre itself is one of the least interesting things to me.
Maybe not the game for me since there's not much fundamentally wrong with it but I would say there are many better uses of your money even in the genre.

Picked this up on sale for $.50 - worth every penny and then some.\n\nCritical Mass is an action puzzler in which the player races to eliminate all of the colored puzzle pieces by placing incoming pieces straegically to connect four connecting colors. Despite the description, it's not particularly innovative." The game is similar in style to something like Tetris in which you have to manage the incoming colors in order to reduce size before it reaches
hoursPlayed: and the menus are swift. All works together perfectly to keep you in the action. I only have two complaints for this game. First
voteText: the player is unable to rotate the shape (it slowly rotates on its own)
helpfulPercent: so the camera angle can sometimes obscure the best place to insert a block. Secondly
votesHelpful: every time I lauch the game on my MBP
votesTotal: it searches all available drives - I launch and then my optical drive fires up. I have no idea why this would ever be necessary for this game (or any other). Regardless
votesFunny: it's loads of entertainment for the prce. 12/13"

Game performs well and has nice graphics.

Critical Mass asks a simple question: What happens when you turn a Match-3 game into a 3D model? And that is what you get: A mass of cubes that requires you to match 4 cubes of the same colour to clear the level, and the idea alone is rather fascinating...\n\n...Except that the main mode is basically a time trial mode, where the mass of cubes expands all the time and explodes at critical mass" level. Once it does that
date: the whole level restarts and you lose all your previous power-ups.\n\nI find this implementation frustrating
recommended: as it never gives you the right breathing room to think about your cube placements. I understand that there is a Zen Mode where you are free to clear cubes at your own pace
hoursPlayed: but the fact that I can't play through the vanilla ranked mode properly leaves a bad taste to me. If only they have a time limit for each level instead of making the mass of cubes a timed bomb
voteText: I would have enjoyed this game much more."

so, you can see i played this game quite a bit, i got in the top 10 at the leaderboard.

this is a game with a decent amount of depth for the price, its not an incredible game but its really fun and the music is incredibly hypnotizing (i say music, its one song, some ambient/trance).

i would recommend it, come on its 2$. even if you play it an hour you got your moneys worth

My Thoughts: This gameplay is really fun and hard at the same time. I had fun playing this game but I got bored of it really fast. It is all the same after you play it and there isn't that many modes to select. Not that much to do in this game but every time you play it you get a different gameplay experience. The Game is really cheap too making it a good price.

Rate: 7/10


Overall: I do recommend this game to everyone!
What else needs to be said about a puzzle game that is so free formed? Don't change a thing about this one. If you want to kill some time while using your brain, this game is for you.
